title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Definition
Spatial interpolation is the estimation of values of spatially continuous variables (fields) for spatial locations where they have not been observed, based on known (observed) values.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Geostatistics
Discipline concerned with modelling, estimation, and simulation of spatially continuous phenomena.
The typical problem is a missing value problem: from a limited number of observations of phenomenon Z(s) at samples \(s_i\), we are interested in estimating values for unobserved locations.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
General equation
\(Z_t\) is the estimated value at point t, \(Z_i\) is the value observed in the i-th point and \(N\) is the number of neighboring points that are used.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Interpolation types
A global interpolation uses all available known points to estimate the unknown values. It produces smoother surfaces.
Local interpolation uses a sample of known points to estimate the unknown values. It captures the short-range variation.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Deterministic vs stochastic
Deterministic method are based on exactly predetermined functions that supposedly captures spatial similarity patterns.
Stochastic interpolation methods use random functions that quantifies the spatial autocorrelation among observations and account for the spatial configuration.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Deterministic vs stochastic â€¦
Deterministic interpolation methods provide no assessment of errors with predicted values, while stochastic interpolation method offer assessment of predictions errors with estimated variances.
Deterministic interpolation methods include inverse distance weighted (IDW), modified Shepard, Spheremap and nearest neighbor.
Stochastic interpolation methods: ordinary kriging and universal kriging.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Nearest Neighbor (NN)
The nearest neighbor method assigns the value from the nearest observation to a certain grid node. It is mostly applied in meteorology and can give good results when using a dense station networks.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: Inverse distance weighting (IDW)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: IDW â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
IDW â€¦
The choice of Î² values affects the estimation quality. Higher values emphasize the influence of nearest points nearest to the grid node. Smaller values give more influence to distant points.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
IDW â€¦.
The choice of the decorrelation distance affect the smoothness of the interpolated surface. A higher value of \(d_0\) results in a more smoothed interpolated surface.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: IDW illustration

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
root-mean-square error (RMSE)
A common interpolation assessment metric is the RMSE:

text: Estimation of the mean function

text: Modelling the semivariogram

text: Spherical model

text: Exponential model

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: Gaussian model

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: Power model

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text: Ordinary kriging (OK)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 13 Spatial interpolation
text:
Universal kriging (UK)

UK, also known as Regression Kriging, is a more general model.
In OK, the trend is a constant value.
In UK, the trend is a linear function of one or more covariates.

text:

 ## Inverse distance weighting (IDW)
 ## IDW â€¦

IDW â€¦
The choice of Î² values affects the estimation quality. Higher values emphasize the influence of nearest points nearest to the grid node. Smaller values give more influence to distant points.

IDW

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: XXX

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text:
Landforms
A landform is a discrete morphologic feature â€” such as a watershed â€” that is formed by a specific geomorphological. Each landform may be composed of several landform elements.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: Gradient

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text:
Slope
The Slope is the steepness at each cell of a raster surface. The lower the slope value, the flatter the terrain; the higher the slope value, the steeper the terrain.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 12 Spatial interpolation
text:
Aspect
The Aspect is the direction the downhill slope faces. The values of each cell in the output raster indicate the compass direction the surface faces at that location.

title: 2015896 - GEOMATICA BASICA
text:
ğŸ“‘ Course Brief
Focus: the focus of this course is introduce concepts, methods and tecniques used in geoinformation disciplines.
How: reading, learning by doing and writing


ğŸ¯ Learning Objectives

Appraise the usefulness of geospatial data for supporting agronomy.
Understand basic concepts about geodesy, cartography, GIS, remote sensing, and geostatistics.
Be able to apply geospatial techniques for data collection, processing, visualization and analysis.
Develop critical spatial thinking.


Select Academic Year/Term:
 2024

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 02 - Geospatial data and geographical information
text:
In this week, we will cover the following topics:
Theoretical topics:
What are the most important characteristics of geographic data?
How are geographic data transformed into information?
What conceptual models are used to represent geographic objects and phenomena
What are the most commonly used data structures and formats?
Practical exercises:
Download and visualize geographic data
Review of geographic metadata

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 5Multidimensional poverty
text:
Monetary poverty
Poverty is about not having enough money to meet basic needs including food, clothing and shelter. However, poverty is more, much more than just not having enough money (Economic and social inclusion Corporation).

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 5Multidimensional poverty
text:
Multidimensional poverty
Poverty is hunger. Poverty is lack of shelter. Poverty is being sick and not being able to see a doctor. Poverty is not having access to school and not knowing how to read. Poverty is not having a job, is fear for the future, living one day at a time (WB).

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
What is a DEM?
A digital elevation model (DEM) is a general term representing ground elevation above sea level. In a DEM, all surface features (trees, buildings, bridges, etc.) are stripped away, and only the bare earth is represented.
A DEM shows:

Heights above sea level
Slopes
River beds
Landforms

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: DEM representation

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: GRID vs TIN

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
What is a DTM?
A digital terrain model (DTM) is a layer â€˜on topâ€™ of the DEM. It will show additional information that the bare earth DEM might not represent, including things like:

Breaklines are changes in the terrain on a surface
Manmade and natural linear features of the bare earth terrain, such as roads, railway tracks, flood defences, pipelines, coastlines, or rivers.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
What is a DSM?
A digital surface model (DSM) is a type of terrain that includes all features above the bare earth - both natural and man-made.
It includes ground features such as buildings, infrastructure, trees, and vegetation. The layer will represent the height of all these features above the ground on which they stand.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: DTM vs DTM (1)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: CHM

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
Uses of DEMs & DTMs
DEMs and DTMs help us understand the â€˜naturalâ€™ shape of the earthâ€™s surface - without the â€˜distractionâ€™ of buildings, trees, or other infrastructure.
Both are especially useful for things like:

Hydrology
Terrain form
Slope stability
Simulations

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
Uses of DSM
DSMs show you both ground elevation and the height of everything above it. This allows you to understand how ground features interact with one another and the bare earth.
DSMs are useful for things like:

Radio frequency planning
Emergency planning
Line of sight planning
Smart city mapping

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: DSM vs DTM (2)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: DEM projects

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text: Spatial resolution

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models
text:
Tecniques
Elevation data can be measured by:

field surveying
photogrammetry
cartographic digitization
airborne laser scanning

text: Field surveys

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 09Digital elevation models

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text:
Definition
Geomorphometry is the science of quantitative land-surface analysis. It is an analytical-cartographic approach to representing bare-earth topography by the computer manipulation of terrain height.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Applications

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Input data

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text:
Parameters vs Objects
A land surface parameter is an attribute of surface form (e.g.Â slope, aspect, wetness index); it is a raster.
A land surface object is a discrete spatial feature (e.g.Â watershed line, cirque, alluvial fan, drainage network): it is a vector.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Workflow

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text:
Landforms
A landform is a discrete morphologic feature â€” such as a watershed â€” that is formed by a specific geomorphological. Each landform may be composed of several landform elements.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Gradient

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text:
Slope
The Slope is the steepness at each cell of a raster surface. The lower the slope value, the flatter the terrain; the higher the slope value, the steeper the terrain.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text: Slope â€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
text:
Aspect
The Aspect is the direction the downhill slope faces. The values of each cell in the output raster indicate the compass direction the surface faces at that location.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 10 Geomorphometry
